{{About|the film|the song|Touched by the Crimson King}} {{Infobox film | name = Terror Train | image = Terrortrainposter.jpg | caption = Original theatrical one-sheet, prominently featuring the villain in a [[Groucho Marx]] mask | director = [[Roger Spottiswoode]] | producer = [[Harold Greenberg]] | writer = [[Thomas Y. Drake|T.Y. Drake]] | starring = [[Ben Johnson (actor)|Ben Johnson]]
[[Jamie Lee Curtis]]
[[Hart Bochner]] | music = [[John Mills-Cockell]] | cinematography = [[John Alcott]] | editing = Anne Henderson | studio = [[Astral Media|Astral Bellevue Pathé]]{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=136}}
[[Sandy Howard|Sandy Howard Productions]]
Triple T Productions | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = October 3, 1980 | runtime = 97 minutes{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=137}} | country = Canada
United States{{cite web|url=http://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/MovieDetails/56515?cxt=filmography|title=Terror Train (1980)|work=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|accessdate=April 15, 2018}} | language = English | budget = [[US dollar|USD]]$4.2 million{{cite book|first=Aubrey|last=Solomon|title=Twentieth Century Fox: A Corporate and Financial History|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=1989|p=259|isbn=978-0-8108-4244-1}} | gross = USD$8 million{{cite news|title=The New Dealmakers: Killing Them at the Box Office: Dealmakers--Killing Audiences |author=Knoedelseder, William K, Jr.|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=November 9, 1980|p=N3}} }} '''''Terror Train''''' is a 1980 [[slasher film]]{{sfn|Rockoff|2016|p=14}} directed by [[Roger Spottiswoode]] in his directorial debut and starring [[Jamie Lee Curtis]], [[Ben Johnson (actor)|Ben Johnson]], and [[Hart Bochner]]. Set aboard a moving train on [[New Year's Eve]], the film follows a group of medical school students holding a costume party who are targeted by a killer who steals their costumes after murdering them to avoid being caught. It features supporting performances from Sandee Currie, [[Anthony Sherwood]], and [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]]. The concept for the film was based on an idea by executive producer Daniel Grodnik, who sought to "make ''[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]'' on a train." A full-length script for the film was composed by [[Thomas Y. Drake|T.Y. Drake]], and production was initiated within four months. The film was shot in [[Montreal]] between late November and late December 1979, shortly after Curtis had completed filming for ''[[Prom Night (1980 film)|Prom Night]]'' (1980). An independently-produced film, ''Terror Train'' was purchased for distribution by the major studio [[20th Century Fox]], who had yet to release a slasher film; the studio was able to supply an expansive marketing campaign for the film that cost an estimated $5 million. It was released theatrically in the United States on October 3, 1980, grossing $8 million during its theatrical run. == Plot == At a college [[fraternity]]'s [[New Year's Eve]] party, a reluctant Alana Maxwell is coerced into participating in a [[prank]]: she lures the shy and awkward [[Fraternities and sororities#Joining|pledge]] Kenny Hampson into a darkened room on the promise of a sexual liaison. However some other students have placed a woman's corpse (stolen from the university medical school during the [[School holiday|Christmas vacation]]) in the bed instead. Kenny is traumatized by the prank and is sent to a [[psychiatric institution]]. Three years later, the members of the same fraternities and sororities hold a New Year's Eve [[costume party]] aboard a [[train]]. Class clown Ed is disguised as [[Groucho Marx]]; Prank ringleader Doc Manley is disguised as a [[monk]]; Jackson is disguised as an [[Extraterrestrials in fiction|alien]] [[lizard]]; Doc's girlfriend, Alana's best friend Mitchy, is disguised as a [[witch]]; and Alana's boyfriend Mo is disguised as a [[bird]]. Also along are Carne, the train conductor, and a [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] hired to entertain the crowd. Ed is murdered prior to boarding and the killer dresses himself in Ed's Groucho Marx mask, allowing him to board the train unnoticed. As the train journeys into the wilderness, the killer wanders amongst the students, who believe him to be Ed. In the [[sleeping car|sleeper]] bathroom, he murders Jackson by smashing his head into a mirror. Carne finds Jackson's bloodied body in the bathroom, still donning the lizard costume. When Carne returns to the scene with the brakemaster Charlie, the killer has hidden Jackson's body and is now posing in the lizard costume; as he appears conscious, Charlie assures Carne that the partygoer was merely drunk. Mitchy goes with the killer, whom she believes to be Jackson, to a [[Sleeping car#Compartments and Double Bedrooms|compartment]] where she attempts to seduce him. As she closes her eyes, he caresses her with Jackson's severed hand before murdering her. Carne subsequently finds her corpse in the compartment with her throat slashed. Alana stumbles upon the scene, and Carne informs her that Mitchy is dead. During a magic show held by the magician and his female assistant, Doc finds Mo stabbed to death, though the partying onlookers assume the scene to be a prank. Carne stops the train and sequesters the students in one car; while doing so, two [[pullman porter]]s find the corpse of Pet, another student. Suspecting Kenny may be involved, Alana recalls the prank to Doc, and recounts her attempt to visit Kenny at the psychiatric hospital. Doc subsequently seals himself inside a room in the sleeper car where the killer is hiding, and is murdered; shortly after, Alana and Carne find his [[decapitation|decapitated]] body. Believing the magician may be Kenny in disguise, Alana notifies Carne, who goes to lock him inside the parlor car; there he finds the magician's female assistant, but the porters are unable to find the magician. Alana is sequestered in a locked compartment for her safety, which the masked killer infiltrates with an axe, and she is pursued through the train. While in-between cars, she manages to push the killer overboard, unaware that he has managed to hold on below. After finding the magician's body in his [[Indian Basket Trick|sword box]], Alana runs through the train car and finds Charlie seated with his head resting in his hands. She tells him the magician is dead, and lays her head on the table, when he grabs her by her wrists. As she looks up, she realizes it is Kenny dressed in Charlie's uniform. He removes the cap, revealing a blonde wig, and Alana realizes he had been posing in [[drag (clothing)|drag]] as the magician's female assistant. Alana apologizes to Kenny about the prank, but he refuses to accept and forces her to kiss him; the kiss causes Kenny to relive his memories from the prank and drives him deeper into insanity. Carne rushes to the scene and beats down Kenny with a shovel, causing him to fall out the open door of the baggage car to his presumed death. His body lands in a nearly frozen river and floats away as the train roars off. ==Cast== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Jamie Lee Curtis]] as Alana Maxwell *[[Ben Johnson (actor)|Ben Johnson]] as Carne, Train Conductor *[[Hart Bochner]] as Doc Manley *Sandee Currie as Michelle "Mitchy" *[[Timothy Webber]] as Mo *Derek MacKinnon as Kenny Hampson *[[Anthony Sherwood]] as Jackson *[[Joy Boushel]] as Pet *[[Vanity (singer)|Vanity]] (credited as D.D. Winters) as Merry *Greg Swanson as the Class President *[[Howard Busgang]] as Ed *Elizabeth Cholette as Maggie *[[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]] as The Magician *Don Lamoreux as Shovels *Steve Michaels as Charlie, the Brakeman *Charles Biddles Sr. as Chief Porter *Thom Haversack as Bill Chase }} ==Themes== The motivation for the villain in ''Terror Train'', similarly to other slasher films, is based on [[revenge]];{{cite book|title=Slasher Films: An International Filmography, 1960 Through 2001|author=Armstrong, Kent Byron|year=2003|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-786-41462-8|p=314}} however, as film scholar John Kenneth Muir notes, the film's central organizing principle is "[[magic (illusion)|magic]], or the often undetectable gulf between reality and [[illusion]]...In other words, characters live and die in ''Terror Train'' based, in large part, on how they perceive the reality or non-reality around them." Muir adds: "If the would-be victims can see through the illusion, they tend to survive. If they can't do so, they die. It's as simple that, but this approach makes ''Terror Train'' a more complex and layered film than the average slasher picture."{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=137}} ==Production== ===Conception=== Producer Daniel Grodnik had the idea for the film's central narrative, which he had wanted to be "like ''[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]'' on a train."{{cite av media|title=Destination Death: An Interview with Daniel Grodnik|publisher=Scream Factory|work=Terror Train|medium=Blu-ray featurette|date=2012}} Grodnik had been a friend of ''Halloween'' director [[John Carpenter]] and producer [[Debra Hill]], both of whom gave him their blessing when he told them of his idea. Grodnik pitched the film to American producer [[Sandy Howard]], who was impressed by the concept. The film was the first motion picture directed by Roger Spottiswoode (a former editor for [[Sam Peckinpah]]), who would go on to make such films as ''[[Turner & Hooch]]'' (1989), ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'' (1990), and ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies]]'' (1997). Spottiswoode was hired to direct the film by Sandy Howard on the condition that he also edit the film{{sfn|Rockoff|2016|p=94}} (though Anne Henderson was later brought in to edit).{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=136}} Because it was made under a Canadian [[tax shelter]], Daniel Grodnik was appointed executive producer, as he was legally unable to serve as a primary producer. There was no stage show magician in the original script, but producer Howard was a fan of magic tricks and illusions, so a magician character was written in. Copperfield's character becomes the suspect at one point of the movie, but it turns out to be a red herring when the real killer is revealed to be Kenny Hampson. There is some confusion about David Copperfield's character's name. Twice, in the movie the Conductor calls out to him as "Ken", but this is when it is believed by he and the passengers that he is Kenny Hampson, the murderer. Additionally, his assistant calls out to him as "Ken," but since his assistant is Kenny in disguise, this could have been an intentional misdirection. In the credits, he is simply listed as "The Magician."{{cite av media|title=Terror Train|people=Spottiswoode, Roger (dir.)|year=1980|publisher=20th Century Fox|medium=Film credits}} ===Casting=== Producer Grodnik sought Jamie Lee Curtis for the lead role of Alana Maxwell based on her performance in the successful ''Halloween'', released two years prior. Curtis was also signed on to star in [[Paul Lynch (director)|Paul Lynch]]'s ''[[Prom Night (1980 film)|Prom Night]]'', which she filmed in Toronto two months before production began on ''Terror Train''.{{efn|''Prom Night'' was filmed in the late summer of 1979,{{cite av media| title =The Horrors of Hamilton High: The Making of Prom Night| url =https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3995520/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1| author = Felsher, Michael|medium= Blu-ray featurette| publisher= Synapse Films|year =2014}} while filming for ''Terror Train'' did not begin until November 1979.}} Veteran actor [[Ben Johnson (actor)|Ben Johnson]] was cast as Carne, the train conductor, whom Grodnik said was "amused" to have been in a horror film amongst such a young cast. The majority of the supporting cast was made of Canadian actors, including [[Hart Bochner]], Sandee Currie, and [[Anthony Sherwood]]. The film included a number of untrained actors, including Derek MacKinnon in the role of the villain, as well as illusionist [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]] as the Magician, and rock singer [[Vanity (singer)|Vanity]] as one of the coed partygoers.{{cite web|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|title=Rockers' 20 Best Appearances in Eighties Horror Movies|author=Kreps, Daniel et al.|date=October 31, 2014|accessdate=January 1, 2018|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/rockers-20-best-appearances-in-eighties-horror-movies-20141031/vanity-terror-train-1980-20141031|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223011850/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/rockers-20-best-appearances-in-eighties-horror-movies-20141031/vanity-terror-train-1980-20141031|archivedate=December 23, 2014}} ===Set construction=== [[File:Cheyenne River sleeper in Sandwich, MA.jpg|thumb|Sleeper used in the film, located along a siding in [[Sandwich, Massachusetts]] in 2014]] To create the train for the film, the producers leased an actual [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] locomotive from the [[Steamtown, U.S.A.|Steamtown Foundation]] in [[Bellows Falls, Vermont]].{{sfn|Rockoff|2016|p=94}} The train's engine was renumbered from its original [[Canadian Pacific Railway No. 1293|1293]] to 1881, and, along with five passenger cars, painted black with silver stripes. Afterward, the Steamtown Foundation reverted the engine back to its original number and had it restored to a historic color and lettering scheme. Production designer Glenn Bywdwell crafted the interiors of the train in an [[Art Deco]] style. As of July 2014, Canadian Pacific Railway No. 1293 continues to be an "operable locomotive."{{cite web|series=Steamtown NHS: Special History Study. |url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/steamtown/shs3e.htm|title=Canadian Pacific Railway No. 1293|work=National Park Services|date=February 14, 2002|accessdate=December 31, 2017}} ===Filming=== Principal photography for ''Terror Train'' mainly took place in and around [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec, Canada]]. The shoot began on November 21, 1979, and was completed on December 23.{{cite web|url=http://ihorror.com/jamie-lee-curtis-making-scream-queen-terror-train/|work=iHorror|title=Jamie Lee Curtis: The Making of a Scream Queen – Terror Train|author=Grove, David|date=October 23, 2016|accessdate=December 30, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025192037/http://ihorror.com/jamie-lee-curtis-making-scream-queen-terror-train/|archivedate=October 25, 2016}} The bulk of the film's train sequences were shot first, while the film's opening sequence was shot on December 22, 1979, the penultimate day of the shoot; filming of it took place at a real fraternity house belonging to [[McGill University]]. The final day of shooting (December 23) consisted of a small crew completing the footage of Kenny's body plummeting from the train into a frozen river below, which was shot on location in [[New Hampshire]], United States. The stunt man was reportedly unable to withstand the freezing temperature of the water, leading art director Guy Comtois played the part of the dead killer instead. The interior train sequences posed numerous obstacles for the crew, specifically cinematographer [[John Alcott]], who devised a unique method of lighting ''Terror Train'' given the limited space and scant natural lighting of the sets: He rewired the entire train and mounted individual dimmers on the exteriors of the carriage cars.{{sfn|Rockoff|2016|pages=94–5}} Utilizing a variety of bulbs with different wattages, and controlling them with the external dimmers, Alcott could light the set in a very fast, efficient manner. At times, Alcott also used medical lights-"pen torches"- to hand light the actors' faces,{{Cite web|url=http://www.terrortrap.com/interviews/rogerspottiswoode/|title=All Aboard...If You Dare!: An Interview with Roger Spottiswoode|date=April 2011|work=The Terror Trap|accessdate=December 29, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130203134934/http://www.terrortrap.com/interviews/rogerspottiswoode/|archivedate=February 3, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} as well as [[Christmas lights]].{{cite av media|title=Riding the Rails: An Interview with Don Carmody|publisher=Scream Factory|work=Terror Train|medium=Blu-ray featurette|date=2012}} To capture some of the film's footage, Alcott used a small lens he had previously used while shooting ''[[Barry Lyndon]]''. To achieve the rocking motion of a real train on film, a crew was appointed to push on each side of the stationary train car in order for the interior sequences to appear as though they were taking place on a moving train.{{cite av media|title=All Aboard: An Interview with Ben Glydwell|publisher=Scream Factory|work=Terror Train|medium=Blu-ray featurette|date=2012}} Taking a cue from director [[John Ford]], Ben Johnson originally asked director Spottiswoode to give his character Carne less dialogue in ''Terror Train'', rather than more. Jamie Lee Curtis also provided input in regard to her character during the filming process: The kissing sequence between her character and that of the killer was an idea that she originated: "I just thought that if she kissed him that it would bring a lot of tenderness to the scene and to the film," she recalled. "The kiss was totally my idea. All during filming, I was looking for ways to make my character more interesting but there weren’t many opportunities because most of the film was about the action and the killer." Canadian actor Derek MacKinnon, who played the masked killer, appears in 11 scenes in ''Terror Train'', wearing a different costume or masked disguise in each scene, including his real character of Kenny.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} There was friction between director Spottiswoode and McKinnon during the shoot, which Spottiswoode claimed was a result of his inexperience: "He wasn’t an actor," Spottiswoode recalled. "He was a [[Transvestism|transvestite]] from the streets of Montreal, and he wasn’t familiar with the concepts of a contract and showing up for work on time. In a strange way though he did a pretty good job. He was familiar with that world of cheap theater and was strangely effective." ==Release== The film was purchased for theatrical release in the United States by [[20th Century Fox]], who had recently garnered attention with the release of ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' (1977). The studio spent an estimated $5 million on an advertising campaign for the film, which would be their only foray into the [[slasher film]] sub-genre during its peak years.{{sfn|Rockoff|2016|p=95–6}} The campaign included billboards and trade advertisements, as well as several posters: The first one-sheet featured the killer dressed in the Groucho Marx mask, brandishing a knife; a second one-sheet emphasized the film's college youth setting, including the same image of the killer in addition to a bonfire and a train in the foreground.{{Sfn|Nowell|2010|p=206}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Terror Train'' opened in the United States on October 3, 1980, and grossed an estimate $8,000,000 at the box office.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1980/0TETR.php|title=Terror Train|work=The Numbers|accessdate=December 29, 2017}} ===Critical response=== ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' deemed the film "competent" in a mildly positive review,{{cite web|work=Variety|title=Terror Train|url=https://variety.com/1979/film/reviews/terror-train-1200424652/|accessdate=December 31, 2017|date=December 31, 1980}} while [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film one out of four stars, writing: "The classic horror films of the 1930s appealed to the intelligence of its audiences, to their sense of humor and irony. Movies like ''Terror Train'', and all of its sordid predecessors and its rip-offs still to come, just don't care. They're a series of sensations, strung together on a plot. Any plot will do. Just don't forget the knife, and the girl, and the blood." However, he conceded that "it's not a rock-bottom-budget, schlock exploitation film."{{cite web |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19801009/REVIEWS/10090301 |title=Terror Train |author=[[Roger Ebert|Ebert, Roger]] |work=Chicago Sun-Times|via=RogerEbert.com |date=October 9, 1980|accessdate=December 30, 2017}} {{rating|1|4}} Ed Blank of the ''[[Pittsburgh Press]]'' criticized the film for its lack of characterization and backstory, summarizing: "''Terror Train''. A neat name. A nothing movie."{{cite news|work=[[Pittsburgh Press]]|location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|title='Terror Train' On Wrong Track|p=15|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25795340/the_pittsburgh_press/|via=Newspapers.com|author=Blank, Ed|date=October 3, 1980}} {{open access}} A review in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' praised the film's atmosphere and characterized it as "stylish, scary fun."{{cite news|author=Thomas, Kevin|author-link=Kevin Thomas (film critic)|date=October 3, 1980|p=H19|title=Stylish, scary fun on ''Terror Train''|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25795805/the_los_angeles_times/|via=Newspapers.com|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} {{open access}} Richard Corliss of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' also praised the film's style, calling it "sleek and eerie."{{cite news|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|author=Corliss, Richard|title=Terror Train|date=November 3, 1980|p=105|publisher=Time Inc.}} Bill Kelley of the ''[[Fort Lauderdale News]]'' was critical of the film's "lapses in logic" and clichés, but ultimately deemed it "a respectable (if that's the word) [[exploitation film|exploitation]] movie."{{cite news|work=[[Fort Lauderdale News]]|location=Fort Lauderdale, Florida|p=8C|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25795467/fort_lauderdale_news/|last=Kelley|first=Bill|title='Terror Train' stays right on the horror cliche track|date=October 6, 1980|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}} Jacqi Tully of the ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'' wrote a similarly favorable review of the film, praising it for its pacing, setting, performances, and Copperfield's magic tricks.{{cite news|work=[[Arizona Daily Star]]|last=Tully|first=Jacqi|location=Tucson, Arizona|title='Terror Train' magic is well engineered|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25795192/arizona_daily_star/|date=October 10, 1980|p=59|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}} Writing for the ''[[Statesman Journal]]'', Ron Cowan commended the cinematography and noted that although the film "starts fairly clumsily, [it] does manage some gripping moments toward the last."{{cite news|work=[[Statesman Journal]]|location=Salem, Oregon|title='Terror Train' steams into Southgate Cinema|date=October 8, 1980|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25795919/statesman_journal/|p=3C|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}} Contemporary internet film guide [[AllMovie]] praised [[John Alcott]]'s cinematography, but concluded, "''Terror Train'' is too mediocre a piece of work to raise interest from anyone but the genre's most devoted fans",{{cite web |url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/terror-train-v49126/review |title=Terror Train (1980) |author=Guarisco, Donald |work=[[AllMovie]] |accessdate=December 30, 2017}} ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out London]]'' called it "better than most of its kind."{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/79103/terror-train.html |title=Terror Train|archivedate=December 13, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213075108/http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/79103/terror-train.html |work=[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]] |accessdate=December 28, 2017}} [[Leonard Maltin]] concurred, claiming that the "stylish photography and the novelty of the killer donning the costume of each successive victim lift this slightly above most in this disreputable genre."{{cite book|author=[[Leonard Maltin|Maltin, Leonard]]|title=Leonard Maltin's Movie and Video Guide 2004 |year=2003|p=1394|publisher=Plume|edition=Revised|isbn= 978-0-452-28478-4}} Film scholar Adam Rockoff praised the film for its "style and oppressive atmosphere."{{Sfn|Rockoff|2016|p=95}} Horror fiction scholar John Kenneth Muir also praised the film in his book ''Horror Films of the 1980s'', writing: "The thrill of a picture like ''Terror Train'' is the shrewd manner in which it plays against audience expectations; the sense that the slasher film paradigm gives it parameters which it can then undercut, subvert, and if needs be, violate."{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=137}} The film holds a rating of 33% on review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 12 reviews with an average rating of 4.8/10.{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/terror_train/ |title=Terror Train (1980) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=July 3, 2018}} ==Home media== The film was first released on [[VHS]] home video in 1988 by [[CBS/Fox Video]].{{cite av media|title=Terror Train|publisher=Key Video & CBS/FOX|year=1986|medium=VHS}} The film was released twice on [[DVD]] by [[20th Century Fox]]; once in 2004 as a single edition release{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdempire.com/Exec/v4_item.asp?item_id=617383|title=Terror Train|publisher=dvdempire.com|accessdate=April 9, 2011}} and again in 2008 in a triple pack alongside ''[[Candyman: Farewell to the Flesh|Candyman 2]]'' and the original ''[[The Fog]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdempire.com/Exec/v4_item.asp?item_id=1411663|title=Triple Feature|work=DVD Empire |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} [[Shout! Factory]] released a collector's edition [[Blu-ray]] and DVD combo-pack under their Scream Factory label in October 2012.{{cite web|work=Blu-ray.com|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Terror-Train-Blu-ray/44386/|title=Terror Train Blu-ray: Collector's Edition|accessdate=December 31, 2017}} On December 7, 2017, Scream Factory announced on their official [[Facebook]] page that the Blu-ray was officially [[out of print]].{{cite web|author=Scream Factory|url=https://www.facebook.com/ScreamFactoryDVD/photos/a.130215417115478.24939.103961936407493/1110418302428513/|accessdate=December 28, 2017|title=***OUT-OF-PRINT NOTICE***|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20180101055728/https://www.facebook.com/ScreamFactoryDVD/photos/a.130215417115478.24939.103961936407493/1110418302428513/|archivedate=January 1, 2018|deadurl=yes|df=}} ==See also== *[[List of films set on trains]] *[[List of films set around New Year|List of New Year's Eve films]] ==Notes== {{Noteslist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Works cited== *{{cite book| last=Muir| first=John Kenneth | year=2012 | title=Horror Films of the 1980s| volume=1| location=Jefferson, N.C.| publisher=McFarland| isbn=978-0-786-47298-7| oclc=840902442| ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Nowell|first=Richard|year=2010|title=Blood Money: A History of the First Teen Slasher Film Cycle|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|ref=harv|isbn=978-1-441-18850-2}} *{{cite book|last=Rockoff|first=Adam|year=2016|title=Going to Pieces: The Rise and Fall of the Slasher Film, 1978–1986|publisher=McFarland|ref=harv|isbn=978-0-786-49192-6}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0081617|title=Terror Train}} *{{tcmdb title|92605|Terror Train}} *{{Amg movie|49126|Terror Train}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|terror_train}} {{Portalbar|Film|Horror fiction|United States|Canada|Christmas}} {{Roger Spottiswoode}} [[Category:1980 films]] [[Category:1980 horror films]] [[Category:1980s horror thriller films]] [[Category:1980s thriller films]] [[Category:1980s teen films]] [[Category:1980s mystery films]] [[Category:1980s slasher films]] [[Category:Films about mass murder]] [[Category:1980s teen horror films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Time travel video games]] to [[Category:Video games about time travel]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 23]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game | image = File:The 3rd Birthday Cover.png | developer = [[Square Enix#Product development divisions|Square Enix 1st Production Department]]
[[HexaDrive]] | publisher = [[Square Enix]] | director = [[Hajime Tabata]] | producer = [[Yoshinori Kitase]] | programmer = Kogi Sugimoto | artist = [[Isamu Kamikokuryo]] | writer = Toshimitsu Takeuchi
[[Motomu Toriyama]] | composer = Mitsuto Suzuki
[[Tsuyoshi Sekito]]
[[Yoko Shimomura]] | series = ''[[Parasite Eve]]'' | released = {{Video game release|JP|December 22, 2010|NA|March 29, 2011|EU|April 1, 2011}} | genre = [[Third-person shooter]], [[role-playing shooter]] | platforms = [[PlayStation Portable]] }} {{nihongo|'''''The 3rd Birthday'''''|ザ・サード バースデイ|Za Sādo Bāsudei|lead=yes}} is a [[Third-person shooter|third-person]] [[role-playing shooters|role-playing shooter]] co-developed by [[Square Enix]] and [[HexaDrive]], and published by Square Enix for the [[PlayStation Portable]]. It was released in Japan in 2010 and in North America and Europe in 2011. The game is both the third entry in the ''Parasite Eve'' video game series, based on the [[Parasite Eve|titular Japanese novel]], and a spin-off, having only a loose connection to events from past games. The game features a [[third-person shooter]]-based combat system with role-playing mechanics. A key mechanic is the Overdive ability, which allows the player to possess pre-positioned human allies and inflict damage upon enemies. The game takes place in 2013, a year after creatures known as the Twisted have appeared from beneath Manhattan and decimated the city. To fight back against the Twisted, an investigatory team called the Counter Twisted Investigation (CTI) is formed. Among their number is series protagonist [[Aya Brea]], who was found unconscious and suffering amnesia two years before the game's events. Using her Overdive ability, Aya travels into the past to alter the outcome of battles against the Twisted. At the same time, Aya attempts to find out the origin of the Twisted and regain her memories. ''The 3rd Birthday'' was created as a conceptual rebirth for Aya's character, as well as a means of re-introducing her to the gaming community, with it being over a decade since the last game in the series. Among the staff were Hajime Tabata, [[Yoshinori Kitase]], [[Motomu Toriyama]], [[Isamu Kamikokuryo]], and Aya's original designer [[Tetsuya Nomura]]. Originally announced as an episodic title for mobile phones, the game was later changed into a PSP exclusive. Upon release, the game reached sixth place in Japanese sales charts, and was among the top five games in North American and UK sales charts during its opening months. Reviews have been mixed; critics praised the presentation and several parts of the gameplay, while opinions were mixed about the story, and many cited difficulties with camera control and some of the shooter mechanics. Several reviewers have also made negative comments on Aya's portrayal. ==Gameplay== [[File:3rd Birthday gameplay.jpg|left|thumb|250px|Combat in ''The 3rd Birthday''. Shown is Aya in battle with a Twisted, along with the health of selectable human units, her ammo count, and other [[HUD (video gaming)|HUD]] displays.]] ''The 3rd Birthday'' is a [[Third-person shooter|third-person]] [[role-playing shooters|role-playing shooter]]. The player controls series protagonist [[Aya Brea]] through rendered-to-scale environments in from a third person perspective. The game plays out as a series of missions, between which Aya rests at the Counter Twisted Investigation headquarters, which acts as the game's main hub. In the hub, Aya can receive briefings for missions, view additional documents, buy and customize new weapons. She also has the option to transport back there should she die during a mission. The game can be saved both at the hub and in safe zones within missions.{{cite web|url=http://support.jp.square-enix.com/document/manual/1371/T3BD_PSPmanual_PUBb.pdf?SQEXSC=u3mvbop6dcbv46mkc53v3loo01|title=The 3rd Birthday North American instruction manual|format=PDF|publisher=[[Square Enix]]|accessdate=2015-04-11}} At the end of each mission, Aya is given a grade based on performance, enemies killed, and the number of times she died. Depending on her score, she will earn differing amounts of Bounty Points, a currency used to customize weapons and repair protective gear in the hub area. During missions, players navigate a series of linear linked areas fighting off multiple enemies. Items can be picked up during missions, such as grenades and medical kits. Aya has access to multiple guns for use in combat, including handguns, assault rifles and shotguns. By holding down a button on the controller, Aya automatically aims at an enemy and can fire at will. Taking cover behind objects or shields, or standing idle outside of battle, allows Aya to regenerate health. While in combat, an energy meter is charged and can be activated when full. When activated, Aya entered "Liberation Mode", a state enabling her to move around the battlefield at high speed for a short period of time. In most battle situations, Aya is accompanied by a group of allied NPC (non-playable character) soldiers that the player can direct around the battle area. Available commands include offering supporting fire, directly attacking enemies, or staying behind cover. They can also all fire at the same enemy in certain situations, dealing high damage. Each NPC has a separate health meter, and is permanently removed from battle upon defeat. Central to combat is Overdive, an ability which enables Aya to transmit herself between bodies. If her health is low, Aya can transport into the body of an allied NPC, taking on their health level, position and current weapon in the process. NPCs not controlled by Aya are controlled by the game's AI. Aya can remain in a body for the duration of a level, or until the unit has died. If Aya cannot jump to another body, she dies and the level must either be restarted or exited. Overdive can be activated at any time, enabling Aya to transport around the battlefield to avoid enemy attacks or save herself when her current unit's health is low. Overdive can also be used to attack enemies if Aya maintains a sustained assault. After a time, a triangle icon appears on enemies, allowing her to perform an Overdive attack, dealing high damage to the targeted enemy. During combat, Aya gains experience points and gains experience levels when a certain quantity is achieved. Gaining a level both restores her health and raises her maximum health and energy levels. Weapons also gain levels the more they are used. In addition to leveling up, Aya's stats can be customized using Over Energy (OE) clips found during missions or acquired during Overdive attacks. Using a 3x3 grid accessed in the hub area, certain OE clips grand different stat boosts and abilities. Creating a new grid automatically deletes the effects of the original. ==Plot== The game's story plays out in episodes, similar to a television series, with many events told out of sequence. On Christmas Eve of 2012, monstrous creatures dubbed as "Babels" appear in [[New York City]]. Along with lifeforms spawned by them called the Twisted, they lay waste to the city and consume any human in their path. By the following year, an investigatory team known as the CTI (Counter Twisted Investigation) has been formed. One of the CTI members is Aya Brea, who was found outside St. Thomson's Cathedral in 2010, just before the Babels and Twisted began appearing. Dr. Hyde Bohr, Chief of the CTI, finds that Aya is suffering from amnesia, and that her personality has changed. After taking Aya in, the CTI discovered that she was capable of transferring her soul from body to body independent of time, an ability dubbed "Overdive", which enables her to fight the Twisted. Bohr and the others planned to use this unique ability to travel back through time and prevent the disaster, developing a machine called "Overdive System" to allow Aya to travel into the past and change events. As she embarks on each mission, she is confronted by powerful, sentient Twisted born from corrupted humans, later dubbed High Ones. One such High One is Kyle Madigan, a man she met and fell in love with during ''[[Parasite Eve II]]''. As she defeats each High One, she regains pieces of her memory, most prominently her memories of being engaged to Kyle, and the existence of Eve Brea, her adopted sister. After an incident that saw the CTI HQ and the Overdive device destroyed by the Kyle High One, Aya reunites with Kunihiko Maeda, a man who aided her in ''[[Parasite Eve (video game)|Parasite Eve]]'', to resolve the entire mystery behind the appearance of the Babel, Twisted and High Ones. Aya eventually discovers that Bohr is himself a High One. Bohr masterminded the death of other High Ones in order to form the Grand Babel, which functions like a giant Overdive system. Bohr seeks to dive back in the past to Time Zero, the point where events were set in motion, to fulfill his plan for the survival of his own species from a time war cycle between humans, the Twisted, and the High Ones. Aya battles Bohr and is pulled with him into Time Zero, where she discovers the truth. In 2010 at St. Thomson's Cathedral, Aya and Kyle were going to be married. The Cathedral was attacked by a SWAT team and Aya was killed. Eve attempted to save Aya by sending her consciousness into Aya's body, creating the Overdive ability. The event caused Aya's consciousness to separate from her body and fragment through time to create the Twisted, Eve's consciousness to become trapped in Aya's body, and parts of Eve's body to be transplanted into people close to the pair to create the High Ones. The "Aya" of the main story is in fact Eve in Aya's body. After these revelations, Eve returns to her body and is asked by Bohr to assimilate him and trigger the birth of a new species. Eve refuses, and when Bohr tries to force the process, a reborn Aya shoots him to death. Aya then reveals that to avert the birth of the Twisted and High Ones, the sources (Aya and Eve) must be removed. Expressing her regret at not being able to marry Kyle, she tells Eve to shoot her. In a fit of emotion, Eve switches bodies with Aya before shooting her, creating a new timeline where Eve's body and Aya's consciousness do not exist, erasing the game's events. Though Eve offers to marry Kyle, he refuses and hints that he is going to find Aya. In a post-credits sequence four years after the game's events, Eve is walking the streets of New York and is wished a "Happy Fourth Birthday" by a woman resembling Aya.{{cite book|title=The 3rd Birthday Insider|publisher=Square Enix|chapter=Unfolded Story|isbn=978-4757531130|language=Japanese|date=2011-01-20}} ==Development== Concepts for a third installment in the ''Parasite Eve'' video game series had been around for some time. As work was being finished on ''[[Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII]]'', Nomura voiced his wish to create a new game for the character Aya Brea, and this time it was taken up.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/interview/article/1211430_1493.html|title=クリエーターインタビュー【4】『The 3rd Birthday（ザ・サード・バースデイ）』|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2007-10-22|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427235324/http://www.famitsu.com/interview/article/1211430_1493.html|archivedate=2014-04-27 |deadurl=no}} Despite the story of ''[[Parasite Eve II]]'' not leaving many avenues for a sequel, the development team wanted to take advantage of advancing gaming technology and popularity by creating a mature gaming experience that would re-introduce Aya to players around the world. The main staff consisted of director Hajime Tabata, producer [[Yoshinori Kitase]], creative producer and character designer [[Tetsuya Nomura]], art director [[Isamu Kamikokuryo]], scenario director [[Motomu Toriyama]], and main writer Toshimitsu Takeuchi.{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2007/09/28/all-star-stafflist-for-parasite-eve-sequel|title=All-Star Stafflist for Parasite Eve Sequel|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2007-09-28|accessdate=2015-04-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/event/tgs/2007/1210654_1603.html|script-title=ja:【イベントリポート】『キングダム ハーツ』新プロジェクトの全貌も！ スクウェア･エニックスクローズドシアター徹底リポート|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2007-09-20|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080815205452/http://www.famitsu.com/event/tgs/2007/1210654_1603.html|archivedate=2008-08-15|deadurl=yes}} Nomura requested Tabata as the two had worked well together on previous projects, and Nomura was busy with other projects despite his strong interest. ''The 3rd Birthday'' was originally announced in May 2007 as an episodic mobile game developed by [[Square Enix]] for Japan's [[Freedom of Mobile Multimedia Access|FOMA]] mobile service.{{cite web|url=http://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20070514/3rdbd.htm|title=スクウェア・エニックス、iモード「The 3rd Birthday」発表「パラサイト・イヴ」のアヤの全く新しい物語|language=Japanese|publisher=Game Watch Impress|date=2007-05-14|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628225900/http://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20070514/3rdbd.htm|archivedate=2013-06-28|deadurl=no}} In 2008, during a special Square Enix event, the game was announced to have changed to a game for the [[PlayStation Portable]].{{cite web | date=2008-08-02 | title=【速報】『ファイナルファンタジー アギトXIII』のPSP版発売が決定 DKΣ3713リポート | url= http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1217142_1124.html | language=Japanese| publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|accessdate=2013-10-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029204717/http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1217142_1124.html |archivedate=2013-10-29 |deadurl=no}} Part of the reason, as stated by Nomura, was that the desired level of realism was not possible on mobile phones. The game became exclusive to PSP as Tabata wanted to make full usage of the platform's hardware capabilities, along with it being a gaming platform available worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-3rd-birthday-impressions-and-interview/1100-6266275/|title=The 3rd Birthday Impressions and Interview|author=Parker, Laura|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=2010-06-16|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408185718/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-3rd-birthday-impressions-and-interview/1100-6266275/|archivedate=2015-04-08|deadurl=no}} Tabata and his team worked on ''The 3rd Birthday'' at the same time as fellow mobile-turned-PSP title ''[[Final Fantasy Type-0]]''. Square Enix requested Tabata to concentrate on finishing ''The 3rd Birthday'', leading to ''Type-0'' almost being cancelled.{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2015/03/16/tabata-final-fantasy-type-0-was-almost-cancelled|title=Tabata: Final Fantasy Type-0 Was Almost Cancelled|last=Moser|first=Casside|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2015-03-15|accessdate=2015-03-15|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X4H51FBY?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/16/tabata-final-fantasy-type-0-was-almost-cancelled|archivedate=2015-03-16|deadurl=no|df=}} The final version of the game was co-developed by Square Enix and [[HexaDrive]], a company created by former [[Capcom]] staff members. As the new form of ''The 3rd Birthday'' had transformed into a third-person shooter, Square Enix wanted staff members with experience at developing such games, and then-company CEO [[Yoichi Wada]] recommended HexaDrive to Tabata. As multiple HexaDrive staff members had also worked on fellow shooter ''[[Lost Planet: Extreme Condition]]'', Tabata agreed to the collaboration.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201504/06075460.html|title=『FF零式HD』の開発を手掛けたヘキサドライブ松下社長に直撃！　田畑Dとは『FFXV』でも……!?|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|language=Japanese|date=2015-04-06|accessdate=2015-04-06|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XaP78PWu?url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201504/06075460.html|archivedate=2015-04-06|deadurl=no|df=}} While aiming for a high quality product, the team designed the game as if for the [[PlayStation 3]] home console, then worked to fit it onto the PSP. During development, the team sought creative help from the team developing ''[[Final Fantasy XIII]]'' for the visual design. The team had previously experimented with shooters with ''[[Dirge of Cerberus: Final Fantasy VII]]'', but this time they wanted to create something closer to a third-person shooter.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/24037325.html|script-title=ja:『ザ・サード バースデイ』開発者インタビュー【その3】――衝撃のラスト。キーワードは... ...|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2010-12-24|accessdate=2014-09-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911002223/http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/24037325.html|archivedate=2014-09-11|deadurl=no}} The team was assembled by Tabata based on their development experience with action games. While working inside the control and hardware limitations of the title, the team created firearms and the lock-on mechanic as the fundamental attack action, instead of the free-roaming style of a standard third-person shooter. While designing levels to function with the game's Overdive system, the team considered what the level would hold, how often players would utilize the function, the difficulty of levels, and the positioning and strength of enemies. During development, a questionnaire was circulated around company staff concerning the character Aya, to find out which of the planned features was popular. One of those that survived in the final game was Aya's clothes being damaged when she was hit by an enemy, which was used to emphasize her sexuality.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/22037175.html|script-title=ja:『ザ・サード バースデイ』開発者インタビュー【その1】――シャワーシーンでレーティングが... ...|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2010-12-22|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204035317/http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/22037175.html|archivedate=2014-02-04|deadurl=no}} Nomura was among the first to suggest this feature originally. Nomura worked on the character designs for the main cast. He was originally only going to work on Aya and Eve, but after seeing the settings for the other characters, he offered to design them too. The team wanted to emphasize the character's sexuality. As part of this, the team included a scene where Aya takes a shower. This was inspired by a similar scene in ''Parasite Eve II''.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/compje/3rd_birthday_dev_interview/|title=The 3rd Birthday Developer Interview|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=Andriasang.com|date=2010-09-27|accessdate=2014-09-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225030201/http://andriasang.com/compje/3rd_birthday_dev_interview/|archivedate=2012-12-25|deadurl=no}} When the title was being developed for PSP, the team's main challenge with the character was to make her look as realistic as possible while retaining her established physical traits. Using this new realism, the team wanted to portray the fear felt by humans when faced with such threats through Aya. Achieving this realism proved one of the most difficult aspects of development.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/23037180.html|script-title=ja:『ザ・サード バースデイ』開発者インタビュー【その2】――スペックの高いハードでアヤを描く機会を... ...|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2010-12-23|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911115438/http://www.famitsu.com/news/201012/23037180.html|archivedate=2014-09-11|deadurl=no}} Her alternate costumes were not a high priority for the team, so their artists had high creative freedom.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/03/16/the-3rd-birthday-interview-dives-into-the-game-with-director-hajime-tabata/|title=The 3rd Birthday Interview Dives Into The Game With Director Hajime Tabata|author=Yip, Spencer|publisher=Siliconera|date=2011-03-16|accessdate=2014-09-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603220654/http://www.siliconera.com/2011/03/16/the-3rd-birthday-interview-dives-into-the-game-with-director-hajime-tabata/|archivedate=2013-06-03|deadurl=no}} While many of the concepts for the final version were present in the original mobile version, such as Overdive and the Twisted, the original story was scrapped when the game changed platforms.{{cite web|url=http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2010/06/30/tetsuya_nomura_3rd_birthday/|title=More 3rd Birthday Talk From Tetsuya Nomura|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=Andriasang|date=2010-06-30|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830194633/http://www.andriasang.com/e/blog/2010/06/30/tetsuya_nomura_3rd_birthday/|archivedate=2010-08-30|deadurl=no}} In creating the story for ''The 3rd Birthday'', the team took inspiration from the 10-year gap in the character's in-game and real-time history. This meant that it would be difficult to create a straightforward sequel, so the team instead decided to make the game about Aya's return. Toriyama imagined story concepts such as the snowy New York setting and the image of a bloodstained wedding dress. These two concepts survived the platform change. Over the course of the development, he adjusted the plot numerous times to be more adult-oriented and to include complex narrative twists.{{cite web |author=Gantayat, Anoop |date=2010-11-23 |url=http://andriasang.com/comrw1/toriyama_3rd_birthday/ |title=The 3rd Birthday: Motomu Toriyama Shares His Thoughts |publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225032939/http://andriasang.com/comrw1/toriyama_3rd_birthday/|archivedate=2012-12-25|deadurl=no}} The original concept was to make the game feel like a television drama, with multiple cliffhangers and moments of high drama. The game was designed from the outset as having no direct connection to the previous ''Parasite Eve'' games.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1236866_1124.html|title=『FF』シリーズのクリエイターが集結した、『ザ・サード バースデイ』インタビュー完全版|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2010-06-25|accessdate=2015-04-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150319041542/http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1236866_1124.html|archivedate=2015-03-19|deadurl=no}} The game's title came from it being Aya's third video game appearance, as well as it being a noticeable change in setting. The game's logo was designed to both look like the letter "B" and the number "3". It was originally only going to represent the number, but Nomura added the extra lines to display the game's "multi-faceted" nature. A notable addition was the option to skip cutscenes, a feature the team regretted leaving out of ''Crisis Core''.{{cite web | author=Gantayat, Anoop| date=2010-10-14| title=The 3rd Birthday Has Skippable Event Scenes| url=http://andriasang.com/comq6w/3rd_birthday_and_crisis_core/ | publisher=Amdriasang | accessdate=2010-10-14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225031024/http://andriasang.com/comq6w/3rd_birthday_and_crisis_core/|archivedate=2012-12-25|deadurl=no}} ==Music== {{Main|Music of the Parasite Eve series}} The music for ''The 3rd Birthday'' was composed by Mitsuto Suzuki and [[Tsuyoshi Sekito]], with additional work by original ''Parasite Eve'' composer [[Yoko Shimomura]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sound-byte-meet-the-composer-behind-the-3rd-birthday/1100-6330891/|title=Sound Byte: Meet the Composer behind The 3rd Birthday|author=Tong, Sophia|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=2011-08-25|accessdate=2015-04-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409161140/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sound-byte-meet-the-composer-behind-the-3rd-birthday/1100-6330891/|archivedate=2015-04-09|deadurl=no}} Shimomura was involved from an early stage, when ''The 3rd Birthday'' was still a mobile game. When she was originally asked to compose for the title, she was involved with a number of other projects which made handling the entire score difficult. When asked whether she wanted to work with anyone on the composition, she suggested Suzuki and Sekito. The general instruction was to follow the pattern used by the music for ''Parasite Eve'', with Suzuki and Sekito handling the majority of tracks, going so far as referring to the songs from the original ''Parasite Eve'' when handling remixes of old themes. In keeping with the game's other development goals, Shimomura wanted to alter some of the established music, although she asked the team to include familiar themes from earlier games for fans. Suzuki was responsible for a large amount of track mixing. Sekito was mostly involved with choosing and helping with instrumentation, in particular whether to include symphonic music. The composers had a relatively high degree of freedom, but they also had problems when composing some tracks that did not fit into selected scenes. Re-orchestrations of two pieces of classical music, "[[Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme, BWV 140|Sleepers Wake]]" by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]], and "[[Joy to the World]]", a popular Christmas song, were used by Suzuki and Shimomura respectively to represent key moments and motifs within the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201101/09039068.html|script-title=ja:『ザ・サード バースデイ』の楽曲に迫るインタビュー完全版！|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2011-01-09|accessdate=2015-04-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804061313/http://www.famitsu.com/news/201101/09039068.html|archivedate=2012-08-04|deadurl=no}} The order of songs in the game was created to reflect the situation in a level. These variations were emphasized during mixing, while they also needed to adjust the mixing and track length based on the game as a whole. For the game's theme song, the company collaborated with Japanese rock band [[Superfly (band)|Superfly]]. The game's theme song [[Eyes on Me (Superfly song)|Eyes on Me]], described as a "standard love song", was specially composed by the band for the game.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comqo0/3rd_birthday_eyes_on_me/|title=The 3rd Birthday's Theme Song is "Eyes on Me"|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=Andriasang|date=2010-10-27|accessdate=2015-04-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225031750/http://andriasang.com/comqo0/3rd_birthday_eyes_on_me/|archivedate=2012-12-25|deadurl=no}} It was the band's first video game theme song.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201407/24057732.html|title=『テイルズ オブ ゼスティリア』 新キャラ＆"リアルマップバトル"や"マップアクション"など新情報をお届け　テーマソングアーティスト・Superflyのコメントも！|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=24 July 2014|accessdate=21 January 2015}} The game's soundtrack was released as an album by Square Enix on December 22, 2010. ''The 3rd Birthday Original Soundtrack'' contains 66 tracks across 3 discs and has a total length of 2:56:52.{{cite web |url=http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/3rdbday/index.html |title=The 3rd Birthday OST |last=Meyerink |first=Stephen |date=2011-01-23 |publisher=RPGFan |accessdate=2015-04-13}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 71/100{{cite web|title=The 3rd Birthday|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/psp/the-3rd-birthday|accessdate=2011-04-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715090832/http://www.metacritic.com/game/psp/the-3rd-birthday|archivedate=2014-07-15|deadurl=no}} | 1UP = B-{{cite web|title=The 3rd Birthday Review: Not Quite Parasite Eve (PSP)|author=Parish, Jeremy|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|date=2011-03-25|url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/parasite-eve-3rd-birthday-review|accessdate=2011-04-01|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Xh0ryd4g?url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/parasite-eve-3rd-birthday-review|archivedate=2015-04-10|deadurl=yes|df=}} | EuroG = 6/10{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-04-06-the-3rd-birthday-review|title=The 3rd Birthday Review|author=Reed, Kristan|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|date=2011-04-06|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917032551/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-04-06-the-3rd-birthday-review|archivedate=2014-09-17|deadurl=no}} | Fam = 36/40{{cite web|title=Japan Review Check: The 3rd Birthday, Echochrome 2|author=Gifford, Kevin|date=2010-12-15|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|url=http://www.1up.com/news/japan-review-check-3rd-birthday|accessdate=2011-04-01|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XgnZlDUZ?url=http://www.1up.com/news/japan-review-check-3rd-birthday|archivedate=2015-04-10|deadurl=yes|df=}} | GI = 6.7/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/the_3rd_birthday/b/psp/archive/2011/03/25/review.aspx|title=The 3rd Birthday Review|author=Gonzalez, Annette|publisher=''[[Game Informer]]''|date=2011-03-25|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114070933/http://www.gameinformer.com/games/the_3rd_birthday/b/psp/archive/2011/03/25/review.aspx|archivedate=2013-11-14|deadurl=no}} | GSpot = 6/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/the-3rd-birthday-review/1900-6305558/|title=The 3rd Birthday Review|author=Petit, Carolyn|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=2011-03-25|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410202749/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/the-3rd-birthday-review/1900-6305558/|archivedate=2015-04-10|deadurl=no}} | IGN = 8.5/10{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2011/03/25/the-3rd-birthday-review|title=The 3rd Birthday Review|author=Kolan, Patrick|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2011-03-25|accessdate=2015-04-10}} | VG = 8/10{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/psp/the_3rd_birthday/review.html|title=The 3rd Birthday Review|author=Gera, Emily|date=2011-03-28|publisher=VideoGamer.com|accessdate=2011-04-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008113330/http://www.videogamer.com/psp/the_3rd_birthday/review.html|archivedate=2014-10-08|deadurl=yes|df=}} }} During production, Nomura and Tabata stated that the team were aiming to sell 500,000 copies of the game, a sales-goal based strategy they had previously used for ''Crisis Core''.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comp2k/3rd_birthday_half_million/|title=3rd Birthday Team Aims for Half a Million Units|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=Andriasang|date=2010-09-09|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808095057/http://andriasang.com/comp2k/3rd_birthday_half_million/|archivedate=2014-08-08 |deadurl=no}} During its first week, ''The 3rd Birthday'' debuted at #6 in Japanese gaming charts, selling 140,000 units.{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comt1o/media_create_sales/|title=The 3rd Birthday Sells 140,000 Units First Week|author=Gantayat, Anoop|publisher=Andriasang|date=2010-12-30|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225034600/http://andriasang.com/comt1o/media_create_sales/|archivedate=2012-12-25 |deadurl=no}} By the end of 2011, the game had sold 249,747 units in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://geimin.net/da/db/2011_ne_mc/|title=2011年テレビゲームソフト売り上げTOP1000（メディアクリエイト版）|publisher=Geimin.net|accessdate=2015-04-11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730235703/http://geimin.net/da/db/2011_ne_mc/|archivedate=2012-07-30|deadurl=no}} The game reached the top of the charts for PSP games in North America by the beginning of April 2011, overtaking fellow Square Enix title ''[[Dissidia 012: Final Fantasy]]'' and the PSP port of ''[[The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky]]''. Later that month, it had fallen to #3 in US charts, remaining there into June of that year. In the UK during the same initial period, it reached #3, tailing behind ''Dissidia 012'' and ''[[Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/124211/Saling_The_World_Street_Fighter_IV_Pilotwings_Lead_3DS_Software_Sales.php|title=Saling The World: Street Fighter IV, Pilotwings Lead 3DS Software Sales|author=Cowan, Danny|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=2011-04-01|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410164416/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/124211/Saling_The_World_Street_Fighter_IV_Pilotwings_Lead_3DS_Software_Sales.php|archivedate=2015-04-10|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/124333/Saling_The_World_Just_Dance_2_Zumba_Fitness_Head_Worldwide_Charts.php|title=Saling The World: Just Dance 2, Zumba Fitness Head Worldwide Charts|author=Cowan, Danny|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=2011-04-08|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514205803/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/124333/Saling_The_World_Just_Dance_2_Zumba_Fitness_Head_Worldwide_Charts.php|archivedate=2014-05-14|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/125353/Saling_The_World_inFamous_2_Tops_US_Multiplatform_Charts.php|title=Saling The World: inFamous 2 Tops U.S. Multiplatform Charts|author=Cowan, Danny|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=2011-06-11|accessdate=2015-04-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514121819/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/125353/Saling_The_World_inFamous_2_Tops_US_Multiplatform_Charts.php|archivedate=2014-05-14|deadurl=no}} Japanese gaming magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'' praised the title's gameplay, calling Aya "deeply customizable", finding the Overdive system and its strategic elements exhilarating and saying that those undaunted by the high difficulty would find much enjoyment in repeated playthroughs. Jeremy Parish of [[1UP.com]] called it "an interesting blend of RPG and shooter", praising the working of Overdive. [[Eurogamer]]'s Kristan Reed was less enthusiastic, referring to the conflicts with the Twisted as "relentless and ultimately repetitive", finding the high difficulty off-putting and Aya's movement speed unsuited for battle. ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s Annette Gonzalez enjoyed the control layout and gameplay, but cited difficulties with the camera. Carolyn Petit of [[GameSpot]] said that the game sometimes succeeded in creating tension, but that other battles were frustrating and the camera was difficult. [[IGN]]'s Patrick Kolan was pleased with the effort put into the game, and generally praised the battle and later levels, despite several cases of repetition during the main campaign. Emily Gera of VideoGamer.com found the basic shooter gameplay repetitive, but felt that the gameplay was saved by the Overdive ability and the quality of fights. Parish said the game looked "gorgeous" and the soundtrack "exceptional". Petit praised the CGI cutscenes and varied level environments, and said the score "shifts adeptly between haunting and thrilling to suit the action." Kolan generally called the game one of the best-looking entries on the platform, and praised the soundtrack, despite it being "a little ho-hum". Gonzalez also praised the cutscenes, while citing the environments as "[ranging] from detailed to drab". ''Famitsu'' was less positive about the story, saying that the mix of different elements made it "a bit hard to follow." Parish positively noted connections to the second game, but found the later story developments either confusing or weak, and disliked the way returning supporting characters had been changed. Petit said that those who wanted a straightforward story would be disappointed, and positively noted its exploration of existence, identity, and memory. Her main criticism was with the dialogue, which she referred to as "stilted". Kolan also faulted the voice acting and localization, especially when compared to games such as ''[[Tactics Ogre: Let Us Cling Together]]''. Gonzalez cited the story as intriguing, with "plenty of plot twists". Parish and Petit were both highly critical of Aya's portrayal: Parish disliked both her outfit, which seemed to conform too much female stereotypes in video games, and the clothes-tearing mechanic, which seemed to be included merely to flaunt her sexuality. Petit shared many points of criticism with Parish, also noting that Aya's portrayal of "one-part action hero, one-part submissive sex object" was wrong for a lead character, and that Aya's in-combat vocals were not suited to the game's situations. Reed referred to Aya as "[a] sighing, whimpering lead character". ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://eu.square-enix.com/en/games/3rd-birthday ''The 3rd Birthday'' European Square Enix page] * [http://na.square-enix.com/en/games/3rd-birthday ''The 3rd Birthday'' North American Square Enix page] * [http://www.square-enix.co.jp/3rd_birthday/ ''The 3rd Birthday'' Japanese site] {{ja icon}} * [http://blog.jp.square-enix.com/3rd_birthday/ ''The 3rd Birthday'' official blog] {{ja icon}} * [http://www.square-enix.co.jp/music/sem/page/3rd_birthday/ ''The 3rd Birthday Original Soundtrack'' official website] {{ja icon}} {{Parasite Eve}} {{DEFAULTSORT:3rd Birthday, The}} [[Category:2010 video games]] [[Category:Action role-playing video games]] [[Category:Amnesia in fiction]] [[Category:Cancelled mobile games]] [[Category:Parasite Eve games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable-only games]] [[Category:Square Enix games]] [[Category:Video games about time travel]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games set in New York City]] [[Category:Video games scored by Yoko Shimomura]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Video games featuring female antagonists]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Trade unions in the United States]]; added [[Category:Trade unions in California]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox Union |name= The Animation Guild |country= United States |affiliation= [[AFL-CIO]] |members= 2,550 (2010) |full_name= The Animation Guild and Affiliated Optical Electronic and Graphic Arts |native_name= IATSE Local #839 |image= [[File:The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839 logo.png|250px]] |founded= 1952 |current= |head= [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= Burbank, CA |people=Karen Carnegie Johnson, President
Jeanette Moreno King, Vice President
Jason MacLeod, Business Representative
Paula Spence, Recording Secretary
Robert St. Pierre, Sergeant-at-Arms |website= [http://www.animationguild.org/ www.animationguild.org] |footnotes= }} '''The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839''' is a professional [[guild]] and [[trade union|union]] of [[animation]] artists, writers and technicians. It was formed in 1952. In 2002, the organization changed its name from '''Motion Picture Screen Cartoonists'''. The full name of the organization is The Animation Guild and Affiliated Optical Electronic and Graphic Arts, Local 839 of the [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] and Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Allied Crafts of the United States, its Territories and Canada, [[American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations]]/[[Canadian Labour Congress]]. == Governance == The Animation Guild is governed by its membership, which meets every two months. To supervise the Guild's affairs, every three years the membership elects a sixteen-person '''Executive Board''' by secret mail ballot. The Executive Board meets every month. As of December 2016, the key executives on the Board are: *'''President''': Karen Carnegie Johnson *'''Vice President''': Jeanette Moreno King *'''Business Representative''': Jason MacLeod The Business Representative is the only paid, full-time elected official of the Guild, which also has a paid staff. All other Board members work at studios under the Guild's jurisdiction. == Collective bargaining agreements == The Animation Guild negotiates and enforces [[collective bargaining agreements]], or '''CBA'''s, with companies employing persons under its [[The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839#Jurisdiction|jurisdiction]]. These CBAs: *define terms and conditions of [[employment]]; *set minimum [[wages]], hours and working conditions; *provide for a [[grievance]] procedure, whereby the Guild intervenes on behalf of its members in disputes with their employers; *specify the payment of contributions to the [http://www.mpiphp.org Motion Picture Industry Pension and Health Plans] (MPIPHP), to provide [[health insurance]] and a [[defined-benefit pension]]. The MPIPHP is entirely ''employer-funded'', by hourly contributions and by residuals and supplemental market payments. All of the terms and conditions of Animation Guild CBAs are ''minimums''; that is, any employee working under a CBA has the unrestricted right to negotiate better terms and conditions than those set forth in the CBA. Such better terms and conditions include but are not limited to: *"overscale" wages; *sick pay; *additional [[Annual leave|vacation]] time; *provisions to allow employees to work at home or off-premises. The text of the Guild's current CBAs and sideletters can be found on their [http://www.animationguild.org website]. === Animation Guild 401(k) Plan === Although not part of the CBA, the Guild sponsors a multi-employer, employee-funded [[401(k) plan]] to which virtually all of its employers are signed. The [[401(k) plan]] was administered by [[Mass Mutual]] in the past, but is currently managed by [[The Vanguard Group]]. == Jurisdiction == The Animation Guild's [[jurisdiction]] is determined by its parent body, the [[IATSE]], and as defined in its CBA. === Work jurisdiction === The Guild covers all artistic, creative and technical job categories in the [[animation]] process, with the following exceptions: *'''Animation camerapersons''' are under the jurisdiction of [http://www.cameraguild.com IATSE Local 600]. *'''Track readers''' and '''soundpersons''' are under the jurisdiction of [http://www.695.com IATSE Local 695]. *'''Animation editors''' are under the jurisdiction of the [[Motion Picture Editors Guild]], IATSE Local 700. *'''Animation voice actors''' are covered by the [[SAG-AFTRA|Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists]]. *Generally speaking, '''[[animation director]]s''' of theatrical features are not covered, as they are considered management due to their ability to hire and fire employees, but [[animation director]]s in other media such as television are covered. *Although animation '''[[Television producer|producers]]''', '''production managers''' and non-creative support personnel are not covered under the Guild CBA, [[employers]] will sometimes sign a so-called "non-affiliate" agreement that allows them to cover them for purposes of [[health insurance]] and [[pension]]. *Although most '''animation writers''' are under the Animation Guild's jurisdiction, some are covered by the [[Writers Guild of America, west]]. *So-called "freelancers" are covered under the CBA if they are working as employees of a signator employer. ''Bona fide'' [[independent contractors]] are not covered, since they are not employees of the company for which they perform work. Although the Guild's traditional [[jurisdiction]] was limited to those working on [[animated film]]s, in recent years the Guild has expanded to the point where a significant percentage of its members are employed in motion picture [[computer graphics]]. Today, both [[Computer graphics#2D|2D]] and [[Computer graphics#3D|3D]] artists work under the Guild's [[jurisdiction]], both in [[animation]] and [[live action]]. === Geographical jurisdiction === All of the Animation Guild's current [[collective bargaining agreements]] are with [[employers]] in [[southern California]]. The [[IATSE]] and other IA locals have [[jurisdiction]] over [[animation]] in other areas of the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. == Employers == === Animation studios signed with TAG === As of August 2018, the following [[animation]] studios were signed to [[collective bargaining agreements]] with the Animation Guild: * 4th Floor Productions, Inc. * [[6 Point Harness|6 Point 2]] * [[Sony Pictures Television|Adelaide Productions, Inc.]] * [[ShadowMachine|Alien Animation, LLC]] * Animated Ark, LLC * Animated Productions, Inc. ** [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Animation]] * [[WildBrain|APU, Inc.]] * [[Bento Box Entertainment|Bento Box Animation]] * Box Office Animation, Inc. * Bureau of Magic, LLC * [[Cartoon Network Studios]] * [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc.]] * CRD Productions, Inc. * Cranetown Media, LLC * [[Crest Animation Studios]] * [[Disney Television Animation]] ** [[ABC Studios]] ** Katy Mac Session Productions Inc ** Obelisk Productions, Inc. ** Patricks Road Productions II, Inc. ** Rutherford Bench Productions, Inc. * [[Dreamworks Animation|DreamWorks Animation, LLC]] * DreamWorks Animation Television, Inc. * Dry Lake Productions * Ex Libris Productions, Inc. * Extinct Productions, LLC * Eye Animation Productions Inc. * [[Film Roman|Film Roman, LLC]] * [[20th Century Fox Animation|Fox Animation Los Angeles]] ** Muddy Water Entertainment, Inc. * Fox Television Animation * [[Hasbro Studios]] ** HanWilCad Productions LLC ** My Little Pony G5 Productions LLC ** My Little Pony Productions LLC ** Santini Productions LLC ** Vaughn Hill Productions LLC ** Woodridge Productions LLC * HB Wink Productions * Hi-Test Productions, Inc. * Leon Animation LLC * [[Marvel Animation|Marvel Animation, Inc.]] * Marvel Animation Studio LLC * [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Animation Inc.]] * [[Nickelodeon Animation Studios]] * Original Force 3D Animation * Outermost Reach * Pearl Studio, Inc. * Picrow, Inc. * Pour Animer, LLC * [[Powerhouse Animation Studios, Inc.|Powerhaus Animation, LLC]] * Puny, LLC * [[Rick and Morty]] LLC * [[Titmouse, Inc.|Robin Red Breast]] * [[Frederator Studios|Robin Sue Productions]] * [[Rough Draft Studios]] * [[Starburns Industries|SBI Media, LLC]] * S-D Animation * Skydance Animation, LLC * Snapshot Enterprises, LLC * [[Sony Pictures Animation]] * [[Animal Logic|Splash Happy Animation, LLC]] * Spytime Productions Inc * Streetlight Productions * STX Animation * Television 101, LLC * [[Toei Animation|Toei Doga Productions, LLC]] * [http://www.g7animation.com Tom T Animation/Gang of Seven Animation] * Turner 1050 Productions * [[Universal Pictures|Universal City Studios LLC]] ** Universal Animation Studios, LLC * Viltrumite Pants, LLC * [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] ** The Secret Lab * [[Walt Disney Television Animation]] * [[Warner Bros.|Warner Animation Group]] * [[Warner Bros. Animation]] ** Warner Specialty Productions Inc. * Wild Canary Animation * Zamodo, LLC === Animation studios signed with the IATSE === Guild members are employed at the following studios under [[collective bargaining agreements]] with the [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]]: *[[ImageMovers Digital]] (defunct) *[[Walt Disney Feature Animation|The Secret Lab]] === Payroll companies === The Guild also signs [[collective bargaining agreements]] with [[professional employer organization|payroll companies]]. Payroll companies perform the [[payroll]] and other administrative functions (often including [[human resources]]) for small companies and unincorporated animation projects, and serve as the employer of record for purposes of making Guild [[health insurance]], [[401(k) plan]] and [[pension]] payments, and processing [[grievance]]s. Payroll companies signed to the CBA include: *[http://www.castandcrew.com/ Cast & Crew Production Plr Inc.] *[http://www.entertainmentpartners.com/ EPSG Management Services] (Entertainment Partners) *[http://www.paydayinc.com/ Payday Inc.] *[http://www.quantumpayroll.com/ Quantum Payroll Services, Inc.] == Membership requirements == Membership in the Animation Guild can be acquired in either of two ways: === Membership by employment === [[Animation]] artists, writers and technicians who are hired by [[The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839#Animation studios signed with TAG|employers]] signed to Guild [[The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839#Collective bargaining agreements|CBAs]] will be required to join the Guild after thirty days' employment. The one-time initiation fee consists of two weeks' minimum scale wages for the job category in which the applicant has been hired. Dues are charged quarterly and are also based upon the scale rate for the job category as of the beginning of the quarter. As of August 2008 the highest dues rate is $101.00. === Membership by organizing === [[Animation]] artists, writers and technicians who are employed by companies that do not have TAG agreements, may become members if and when the company is organized. Potential members may assist the Guild in its organizing efforts by signing a confidential [https://web.archive.org/web/20090626113051/http://www.animationguild.org/_QandA/whyorganize/whyorganize_1f.htm representation card]. After the employer is organized and signed to a [[The Animation Guild, I.A.T.S.E. Local 839#Collective bargaining agreements|collective bargaining agreement]], employees often are brought into membership without initiation fees. ==External links== *[http://www.animationguild.org/ The Animation Guild] official Web site *[http://animationguildblog.blogspot.com/ The Animation Guild] blog *[http://tomsito.com/book_about.php Drawing The Line: The Untold Story of the Animation Unions from Bosko to Bart Simpson], by: TAG President Emeritus '''Tom Sito''' {{Animation industry in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Animation Guild}} [[Category:International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] [[Category:Trade unions in California]] [[Category:Entertainment industry unions]] [[Category:American animation]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1952]]

revision.comment: bolding headword; explanatory 1st sentence; less [[WP:PEACOCK]]; +some wikilinks; several [[WP:MOS]] matters.
revision.text:
'''The Faction''' is a London-based theatre company.
The Faction is beginning to develop a real signature in imaginative, contemporary and visceral versions of the classics. Amid the current debate between the rise of new writing and lack of classical work on London stages, this enterprising and determined company is doing us all a service. – The Stage{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/factions-2015-rep-season-romeo-julietthe-talented-mr-ripleyjoan-arc/|title=The Faction;s 2015 rep season: ''Romeo and Juliet''/''The Talented Mr Ripley''/''Joan of Arc''|work=The Stage|access-date=2017-07-14}} It's a bold, brave enterprise – ''[[The Guardian]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/jan/30/the-robbers-review|title=''The Robbers'' – review|last=Billington|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Billington (critic)|date=2014-01-30|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2017-07-14|issn=0261-3077}}
== Company == After seeing the [[Schaubühne]] Berlin at [[Edinburgh International Festival]] in 2004,{{Cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/06778234|title=The Faction Theatre Company Limited – Overview|website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-06}} Mark Leipacher created The Faction Theatre Company in 2008. The Faction became a registered charity in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1145820&SubsidiaryNumber=0|title=Charity overview|access-date=2017-03-06}} Their first production was ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]'' at the [[Brockley Jack Theatre]], London, in October 2008. The Faction is now led by two artistic directors; Mark Leipacher and Rachel Valentine Smith, and is supported by a core ensemble of eleven actors and associate artists.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thefaction.org.uk/ensemble|title=thefaction|website=thefaction.org.uk|access-date=2017-03-06}} ===Ensemble=== *Alex Guiney *Amelia Donkor *Anna-Maria Nabirye *Christopher Hughes *Christopher York *Clare Latham *Gareth Fordred *Jude Owusu *Kate Sawyer *Lachlan McCall *Natasha Rickman ===Associate artists=== *Gareth Jandrell – Playwright *Emily Juniper – Playwright *Suzie Foster – Stage Manager *Max Pappenheim – Sound Designer *Chris Withers – Lighting Designer == History == During The Faction's formative years, they toured across the UK, played studio theatres across London, and established an open-air season in [[Brockwell Park]]. They were then invited to be an associate ensemble of the [[New Diorama Theatre]].
